review_text: One of the coffee shops located in Malioboro street. This place has a variety of drinks, snacks, and dishes to try. We tried one of their mocktails, it tastes okay and has a reasonable price. We also tried some of their snacks, such as the Tahu Cabe Garam, which has nice flavours. The place has indoors and semi-outdoors, with smoking and non-smoking areas, and has nice ambience. The staff here are friendly, and the foods and drinks came out relatively quickly. Overall, a good option to visit in Malioboro.

review_text:
It’s an okay place to hang out, but it’s not really my preference for enjoying coffee. They have several “modern” coffee options (coffee mixed with various things), along with teas and some food.
I ordered Kalamansi Iced Tea and Vietnamese Drip, but they didn’t quite meet my expectations. They served the Vietnamese coffee without the drip tools, and they forgot to give me a spoon to stir it—maybe they rarely serve that one. The cashier didn’t seem to know much about coffee, but fortunately, the waiter was friendly.
There are toilets and a musholla available here.
I think this place is more suitable for Gen Zs.

review_text:
I visited your place today with my brother. While he was ordering coffee, I sat on a bench with decorative lights. Out of nowhere, an exposed, cut-open wire from those lights shocked me.
The jolt hurt that I felt pain right away, and my right leg cramped and went numb. What really surprised me, though, was how the staff handled it. When I told them what happened, all they said was, “Maaf ya, Kak,” without even asking if I was okay or showing much concern. Then they just taped a tissue napkin over the wire. That felt careless and unsafe, especially since the same thing could easily happen to another guest, even a child or an elderly person.
Please take a serious look at this issue. A little more care for your customers could prevent a much worse accident in the future. Sometimes a simple, “Are you okay?” or “How are you feeling?” can make all the difference. Just a little empathy goes a long way.
